criteria: Understanding of Federal Government Spending Categories
descriptions: Demonstrates no understanding of federal government spending categories (defense, welfare, national debt interest, education).
Shows a limited or inaccurate understanding of one or more federal government spending categories.
Identifies federal government spending categories but struggles to provide specific details or examples.
Identifies and generally describes federal government spending categories, including defense, welfare, interest on the national debt and education.
Clearly explains federal government spending categories, providing specific examples of programs or initiatives within each category.
Provides a comprehensive explanation of federal government spending categories, including historical context and their impact on post-WWII America.
Does not address federal government spending on defense.
Mentions defense spending but provides no analysis or context.

Analyzes the impact of defense spending on the economy and society during the post-WWII era.
Critically evaluates the long-term consequences of increased defense spending on American society and foreign policy.
Does not address federal government spending on welfare.

Explains the increase in welfare spending and connects it to the Great Society programs.
Analyzes the impact of welfare spending on poverty rates and social mobility during the post-WWII era.
Critically evaluates the long-term consequences of increased welfare spending on American society and individual liberty.
Does not address federal government spending on education.
Mentions education spending but provides no analysis or context.
Describes the increase in education spending but offers limited insight into the reasons behind it.
Explains the increase in education spending and connects it to the California Master Plan.
Analyzes the impact of education spending on access to higher education and workforce development during the post-WWII era.
Critically evaluates the long-term consequences of increased education spending on American society and educational outcomes.
Makes no mention of the California Master Plan.

Evaluates the success and limitations of the California Master Plan in expanding access to higher education.
